6518.summary: A handcuffed teen was being booked into a US jail when the cop suddenly collapsed in front of him from a heart attack.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: A handcuffed teen was being booked into a US jail when the cop suddenly collapsed in front of him from a heart attack.
metadata.source:
A handcuffed teen was being booked into a US jail when the policeman suddenly collapsed in front of him from a heart attack.

Footage shows the officer, Franklin Foulks, falling to the ground and clasping his chest inside the jail at Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

It was the arrested teen who helped save him, NBC Miami reports.

Jamal Rutledge, who was being charged with criminal mischief and burglary, got up and kicked the fence security gate, yelling for help and pointing to Foulks with his chained hands.

Other officers soon responded and rushed a defibrillator into the room for paramedics to restart Foulks's heart.

Doctors said that if the rescue had taken much longer, Foulks would have died.

Rutledge will now be publicly commended for his actions along with three officers involved in the rescue.

The incident happened in September but the video has only just been released.

Do you have any news photos or videos?

27011.summary: Philip Canlyte is closing its lighting fixture plant in Cornwall, Ont., leading to 190 jobs lost in the small eastern Ontario community.

metadata.source:
Almost 200 jobs will be lost in Cornwall as a lighting fixture manufacturer shuts its doors due to the growing demand for LED lights.

Philips Canlyte made fixtures for bulbs such as this compact fluorescent light bulb (CFL), but says LED lighting has become the norm. (Adrian Wyld/Canadian Press)

​Canlyte, a division of Philips Electronics, is a leading manufacturer and supplier of lighting fixtures and services.

Its Cornwall plant has run for 27 years but now the work will be transferred to other plants across North America, according to Canlyte.

The plant will close over the next 11 months affecting 190 employees.

The company blames less demand from industries and businesses that are turning to LED lighting.

Employees have shared the news, and their resulting frustration, on social media. The town’s mayor also expressed his disappointment in the closure to CBC News.

Cornwall mayor Bob Kilger says the impact on his community is serious after Philips Canlyte announced it's closing its plant. (CBC)

“Two hundred jobs is a large number of jobs in a small community, the payroll, the benefits, and so the direct impact on those employees, their families is serious,” said Cornwall Mayor Bob Kilger.

Kilger said he hoped other plants and new ventures in the area could lead to new job for the workers affected.

Light bulbs are in a time of flux across Canada after the federal government banned manufacturers from supplying incandescent bulbs to Canada beginning on Jan. 1, 2014, as part of rules aimed at improving efficiency.

75658.summary: The two-time London marathon winner Wilson Kipsang has insisted most Kenyan runners are clean despite a glut of positive doping tests

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: The two-time London marathon winner Wilson Kipsang has insisted most Kenyan runners are clean despite a glut of positive doping tests
metadata.source:
The two-time London marathon winner Wilson Kipsang believes that most of Kenya’s distance runners are clean despite a slew of positive drug tests.

Around 40 Kenyan athletes have been banned in the past two years, including the 2013 and 2014 Boston and Chicago marathon winner Rita Jeptoo, but Kipsang believes “maybe 99%” of the country’s athletes can be trusted.

Kipsang, who was speaking after confirming that he would return to contest the London Marathon in April and race the new world record holder Dennis Kimetto, claimed that more needs to be done to educate athletes.

“There are great measures under way now in Kenya to protect the sport,” Kipsang said. “We have seen that many athletes don’t understand what is doping and so we are trying to create awareness and find out how they fall prey in this situation. The ban has been increased from two years to four years, which will also act as a deterrent.”

London Marathon organisers, meanwhile, are delighted after signing up a field that they believe could be its strongest ever. The race not only pits Kipsang and Kimetto – the two fastest marathoners of all time – but also includes six other men who have run under 2hr 5min. The 5,000m and 10,000m world record holder Kenenisa Bekele will also appear in London for the first time.

London Marathon’s international relations spokesman Dave Bedford said the competition would be good for the sport. “We are lucky we have an event where people don’t duck each other and the marathon is a stronger event for that,” he added.

While London’s course is not as fast as Berlin, where Kimetto set a world record time of 2:02:57 in September, Kipsang believes a world record is achievable. “I could try to go for it in London,” he said. “It’s a very nice course. If the weather is OK and the guys are really ready to for a fast time it’s possible on that course.”

Intriguingly, Kipsang said he would like the leading group to go through halfway in 61:35min – 10 seconds quicker than Kimetto’s time after 13 miles in Berlin. But Kipsang insists that with such a strong field he faces multiple threats.

“Eliud Kipchogeis very strong as is Emmanuel Mutai,” he said. “I think even Bekele could be a good challenge and we saw last year what Stanley Biwott did. These are the guys that are really going to be the threat.”

5701.summary: The first 80 metres of tracks for the light rail project have been laid in front of Sydney's Town Hall, 55 years after the tram system was shut down.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: The first 80 metres of tracks for the light rail project have been laid in front of Sydney's Town Hall, 55 years after the tram system was shut down.
metadata.source:
More than 50 years after tramlines ware shut down in the Sydney CBD, the first 80 metres of the light rail has been laid.

Transport Minister Andrew Constance on Monday said it was an historic moment in Sydney's history as the 80-metre track was cemented in place on George Street in front of Town Hall.

"Building this world-class public transport system down one of Sydney's oldest streets has not been without its challenges, but we're getting on with the job," he said.

Last month an audit revealed that the CBD to eastern suburbs light rail link had cost taxpayers and extra $517 million.

Testing on the $2.1 billion rail link is expected to start by mid-2018, with the full service to open by early 2019.

71241.summary:
San Francisco has some of the best career opportunities, compensation, and business confidence of any city in the country, according to a report out Friday from Glassdoor. The city is second only to San Jose when it comes to employee satisfaction.

And the future looks bright: 48 percent of worker

metadata.supported-summary-sentences:
San Francisco has some of the best career opportunities, compensation, and business confidence of any city in the country, according to a report out Friday from Glassdoor. The city is second only to San Jose when it comes to employee satisfaction. 

And the future looks bright: 48 percent of worker
metadata.source:
San Francisco has some of the best career opportunities, compensation, and business confidence of any city in the country,

. The city is second only to San Jose when it comes to employee satisfaction.

And the future looks bright: 48 percent of workers in San Francisco believe business will improve over the next six months, according to Glassdoor. (Twenty percent expect it to get worse.) This is San Francisco’s second consecutive year in the No. 2 spot. San Jose took the top spot, with the highest score for compensation and benefits.

Glassdoor ranked the country’s 50 largest cities based on employee feedback. To make the list, cities had to have at least 700 company reviews posted to Glassdoor from May 2013 to May 2014, and at least 60 business outlook ratings from April 29 to May 28, 2014.

San Francisco ranked third for compensation and benefits and second for career opportunities, with scores of 3.3 and 3.2 out of 5, respectively. There are 7,632 local employers hiring, according to Glassdoor, with some of the most in-demand jobs in software engineering, recruiting, and business analysis. The high-rated companies hiring locally are Twitter, Riverbed Technology, and Genentech.

The lowest-scoring cities were Pittsburgh, Denver, Las Vegas, Tampa, and Phoenix.

The careers website also looked at cities with the most employers hiring. New York topped that list, with 13,332 companies hiring, followed by Chicago and Los Angeles.

View the top 10 cities for employment satisfaction above, along with three of the most in-demand jobs and highest-rated employers in each city, based on Glassdoor ratings. Glassdoor provided quotes from employees in the top five cities on its list.

Glassdoor spoke with San Jose residents about why they enjoy working there. View their video below.

31126.summary: Kenneth Lieberthal: Whether the U.S. and China can cooperate or continue to distrust one another's intentions has huge global consequence.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: Kenneth Lieberthal: Whether the U.S. and China can cooperate or continue to distrust one another's intentions has huge global consequence.
metadata.source:
President Obama and Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping meet at the White House in Washington on February 14.

Editor's note: Kenneth Lieberthal is director of the John L. Thornton China Center at the Brookings Institution. He is the author, with Wang Jisi, of "Addressing US-China Strategic Distrust."

(CNN) -- The United States and China have the most important bilateral relationship in the world. Whether they can develop a constructive, cooperative relationship or whether they become each others' greatest nightmare has enormous consequences for each country and for the capacity of the international system to manage regional and global issues.

Both leaderships recognize what is at stake, which explains why, despite many disagreements, Washington and Beijing constantly stress the importance of building ties. The two governments conduct more than 60 formal dialogues a year and engage each other daily, to a far greater extent than most people realize.

Despite these efforts, each country has an underlying and growing distrust of the other's long-term intentions. Such distrust is corrosive, casting even well-intentioned actions and initiatives in a negative light.

When President Nixon opened the door to Beijing 40 years ago, nobody imagined that U.S.-China relations would develop to this point. But extensive governmental contacts between the nations, economic interdependence and huge flows of students and tourists back and forth have failed to stem the growth of underlying mutual distrust. That distrust could well create a self-fulfilling prophecy of eventual confrontation.

A key problem is that neither government is confident that it understands how the other sees the future of their relationship. Although each side senses distrust in the other, the real reasons for that attitude are unclear. So, how do they separate propaganda efforts designed to manipulate from sincere concerns?

Because this is such a tough and consequential problem, I teamed up with one of China's leading America specialists to write a report that lays out the underlying worries that each side has about the other and, especially, why they have these deep concerns. Our report was published simultaneously last week in English and Chinese.

My colleague wrote, in unvarnished fashion, about the analysis that leads many policymakers in China to believe the ultimate goal of the United States is to constrain or disrupt China's rise and to undermine its political system. I wrote about U.S. hopes for a normal major power relationship with China over the long run and the reasons why many American policymakers are increasingly concerned that this may prove impossible.

The reasons are complicated. In part, they include the inevitable tensions that arise when a global balance of power is changing. My colleague and I expect that America will retain its leading role for many years to come, but the gap between U.S. and Chinese power and position is narrowing. Because of that, many in China fear the United States might resort to anti-Chinese measures to maintain its lead. American officials worry not so much that China will rise, but that Beijing will believe it can only do so at direct cost to the United States.

Our enormously different political systems exacerbate this distrust. Neither side understands very well the political and institutional constraints in the other's system, and both are inclined to assume the other is more strategic, centralized and internally disciplined than it is. Neither is certain that it knows when the other is being honest about its domestic political constraints, and both tend to take random events as reflections of strategic intent.

Beijing views America's pro-democracy foreign policy as aimed, in part, at changing China's system, while Washington inherently distrusts the motives and actions of authoritarian governments. And unsurprisingly, both sides have partially institutionalized distrust in their militaries, intelligence agencies, and offices focused on cybersecurity.

Distrust about long-term intentions is thus grounded in complicated narratives in both countries. Neither side wants an adversarial relationship, but both worry that it may become unavoidable. And extensive efforts to build mutual trust to date are not working.

New measures are necessary. Both governments must discuss, in depth, topics they have been avoiding. What overall military postures in Asia will both permit China to meet its vital security needs and enable America to defend its allies and interests? What kinds of mutual restraint can help bring about this outcome?

How does each side view potential developments on the Korean Peninsula over the coming decade, and how would both plan to react to each scenario?

America conducts surveillance activities just outside China's territorial waters that Beijing views as hostile and degrading. Could China provide some type of increased military transparency that could change this? Could the military component of the Taiwan issue be reduced?

Understanding views of the long term, clarifying thinking on key military issues and devising concrete efforts to build mutual confidence are the initiatives that could alter the perceptions in Washington and Beijing that enhance distrust. The future can be shaped by intelligent actions, but those must be based on clear recognition of the reasons why each side fears the future intentions of the other.

Follow us on Twitter: @CNN Opinion.

The opinions expressed in this commentary are solely those of Kenneth Lieberthal.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: Stars & flops: Brees, Hasselbeck disappoint
metadata.source:
The games of Week 13 mark the end of the regular season for many fantasy leagues.

But unquestionably, the most scrutinized and debated play of the week was Denver quarterback Jay Cutler's first start against Seattle on Sunday night. Cutler was uneven, as you'd expect, but did make several big throws when needed. Rookie Brandon Marshall, who I'd touted for some reason on a Saturday radio appearance, bailed both Cutler and me out by breaking several tackles en route to a 71-yard touchdown run. Cutler finished with two touchdown passes, 143 passing yards and committed three turnovers. Fantasy owners who plugged Cutler in this week certainly appreciated the magical run from Marshall after the strike on the 12-yard out against a zone defense and have to be encouraged by the energy that his insertion seemed to inspire.

Other fantasy owners weren't so lucky, as Drew Brees, Tony Romo and Matt Hasselbeck failed to deliver amid high expectations.

Let's review the performances of Week 13.

The action of Week 13 started back on Thursday with a huge win by the Bengals against the Ravens. The star of the day was T.J. Houshmandzadeh, who hauled in 10 passes for 106 yards and scored on a 40-yard flea-flicker from Carson Palmer. The Ravens are still wondering precisely how Houshmandzadeh got so wide open, and Palmer thanked the fans for alerting him to the fact that Houshmandzadeh had blown past coverage. Palmer completed 21-of-32 passes against the stellar Baltimore defense for 234 yards and the touchdown pass to Houshmandzadeh.

Chad Johnson finished the game with eight receptions for 91 yards. After a slow start to the season, Johnson now has four straight games with at least 91 yards receiving (166 yards per game).

Veteran receiver Derrick Mason made the most of his opportunities on Thursday, hauling in seven passes for 90 yards and a touchdown off the arm of Steve McNair (26-of-43 for 227 yards and one touchdown). Mason has averaged 5.75 receptions per game over the past month.

Reggie Bush finally made his mark on the pro game with his four-touchdown performance against the 49ers. Bush showed tremendous heart and competitiveness in his runs, carrying would-be tacklers toward the goal-line. Bush caught nine passes for 131 yards and added 37 rushing yards in the win. Bush has now caught 73 passes this season.

Deuce McAllister shouldered the heavy load with 26 carries for 136 yards against San Francisco. It was McAllister's second 100-yard game of the year. Unfortunately for fantasy owners, Bush got the call down low this week.

The Chicago defense came up huge on a day when the offense fizzled against Minnesota. The Bears received two touchdowns from the defense and special teams (a Ricky Manning, Jr. interception and Devin Hester punt return) and generated three sacks and five turnovers in the NFC North-clinching game.

The Bears did have one bright spot on offense. Backup running back Cedric Benson spelled starter Thomas Jones with nine carries for 60 yards, including a 24-yard touchdown scamper for the team's only offensive touchdown of the day.

For all of the turnovers committed by the Vikings, they did produce a tremendous running game. Workhorse Chester Taylor carried the ball 17 times for 99 yards (5.8 yards per carry) before leaving with a rib injury. Second-year back Ciatrick Fason replaced Taylor in the backfield and piled up 75 yards on 11 carries including a four-yard touchdown run late in the game. Keep an eye on Taylor's development this week. Fason would make for a solid sleeper pick next week against Detroit if Taylor is unavailable.

Edgerrin James posted his first 100-yard game of the season in the blowout win over St. Louis. James carried the ball 26 times for 115 yards after touching the ball just six times last week against the Vikings. In a disappointment-filled season, James does have one milestone in his reach. James needs to average just 47.5 yards per game over the final month to reach 1,000 yards for the season.

For all of his strong running yesterday, James was the odd man out in the red zone. Marcel Shipp carried the ball seven times for 21 yards and scored three times. Shipp had carried the ball only three times for six yards coming into Sunday's game.

St. Louis running back Steven Jackson continued his phenomenal run as the workhorse against the Cardinals. He rushed for 96 yards and added nine receptions for 69 yards. Jackson has accrued 87 or more yards of total offense in 10 of 12 games this season.

Torry Holt ended his scoring drought with a big game against the Cardinals. Holt had been scoreless in five consecutive games ahead of his seven-reception, 115-yard performance. Holt also reached the century mark receiving for the first time since Week 6.

Holt's longtime partner in the receiving corps, Isaac Bruce, also posted his best game in weeks. Bruce caught five passes for 75 yards and scored for the first time since Week 4.

Marc Bulger contributed his best game for fantasy owners since Week 8 with 314 yards and two touchdowns against the Cardinals. His late touchdown pass to Isaac Bruce with 35 seconds remaining saved what had otherwise been a disappointing game for the Rams. Bulger was also sacked four times and three a season-high three interceptions in this game. After throwing one interception in his first eight games this season, Bulger has now thrown interceptions in four consecutive outings.

Larry Fitzgerald didn't match his ridiculous yardage total of Week 12, but he found the end zone for the first time since Week 5. Fitzgerald caught five passes for 46 yards in the win.

The Redskins raced out to a 14-point advantage over the Falcons on the strength of Ladell Betts' legs and a great adjustment on a deep route by Santana Moss.

Betts and the Redskins' power running game controlled the line of scrimmage, generating 155 rushing yards on 28 attempts. It was Betts' second consecutive 100-yard game and third of the season. Since taking over for the injured Clinton Portis, Betts has topped 80 rushing yards in three of his four starts. His touchdown run was his first since Week 3.

Santana Moss has been slowed by a hamstring injury for weeks, but he gutted it out on Sunday to offer his first touchdown since Week 4. Moss caught seven passes for 123 yards, nearly matching his receiving total in the five games in which he's appeared since that monster Week 4 outing. He made a great read on an under-thrown ball from Jason Campbell for the 42-yard touchdown reception.

Michael Vick silenced his critics, if only for a day, with a tremendous performance in a must-win game against the Redskins. Down 14-0, Vick led the Falcons to 24 straight points for the win. He tossed touchdown passes to Alge Crumpler (his seventh) and Michael Jenkins (his sixth) while completing only 8-of-16 pass attempts for 122 yards. As always, Vick contributed to the bottom line of fantasy owners with 59 rushing yards.

Rookie Jerious Norwood exploded onto the scene with his 69-yard touchdown run against the Redskins. Norwood carried the ball nine times for 109 yards. Norwood topped 50 rushing yards for the second straight game and notched his second 100-yard game of the season.

Detroit receiver Mike Furrey remains one of the game's top surprises and posted another strong effort against the Patriots. The former safety caught nine passes for 123 yards and scored his fourth touchdown of the season. Furrey has topped 60 receiving yards in five of his last six games and now has 65 receptions and 773 receiving yards on the season.

Patriots wideout Reche Caldwell is finally getting to show his talent after years of injury problems. Caldwell caught eight passes for 112 yards in the comeback win over Detroit and has recorded at least 70 receiving yards in four of his last six games.

Lions running back Kevin Jones contributed a tremendous game against the Patriots, but it could have been so much more. Jones rushed for 56 yards and added another 86 yards on five receptions (142 total yards) and lost a crucial fumble inside the Patriots' five-yard line. Still, Jones has accrued 80 or more total yards in eight of the 11 games in which he's appeared this season.

Corey Dillon didn't pile up yardage, but he found the end zone three times in the comeback win. Dillon carried the ball nine times for 25 yards as the primary ball carrier for New England after Laurence Maroney left because of an injury. Dillon has scored 10 touchdowns this season on 141 carries.

Titans rookie quarterback Vince Young has now claimed back-to-back victories over the Manning brothers with a dramatic 20-17 win over the Colts. Young completed 15-of-25 attempts for 163 yards with two touchdown passes and two interceptions. He also added nine carries for 78 yards. Young completed passes to 10 different receivers on the day.

Young connected with Drew Bennett and Brandon Jones for his touchdown strikes. Jones has now caught touchdown passes in consecutive weeks.

Travis Henry piled up 93 yards on 20 carries to aid the winning cause. Henry has now accrued 90 or more rushing yards in three of his last four starts.

Fantasy owners breathed a sigh of relief when Marvin Harrison streaked down the center of the field for an early 68-yard touchdown reception. It snapped a three-game scoreless streak during which Harrison had accrued a total of nine receptions for 123 yards. Harrison finished Sunday's heartbreaking loss with seven receptions for 172 yards and his sixth touchdown of the season. The touchdown was his 100th career score from Peyton Manning.

For his part, Manning completed 75 percent of his throws for 351 yards, one touchdown and two interceptions in the defeat. It was hardly his best effort, but the heavy yardage total certainly helped more than a few fantasy owners. Manning has thrown at least one touchdown pass in all 12 games played this season while throwing for an average of 276 yards.

I always admit an error, and I got the Kansas City-Cleveland game wrong. Cleveland came with a much stronger effort than I expected and Trent Green returned to fantasy prominence in a big way. After two very quiet weeks since returning from injury, Green exploded against the Browns on Sunday. Green completed 24-of-32 passes for 297 yards with four touchdowns against one interception. He still has two very difficult matchups on tap in Weeks 14 and 15 (Baltimore and San Diego), but it's good to have him back in the argument.

Green reconnected with Eddie Kennison (seven receptions for 117 yards and a touchdown) and Tony Gonzalez (nine receptions for 105 yards and two touchdowns). Kennison had tallied only eight receptions for 131 yards in his previous four contests. Gonzalez reached the 100-yard mark for the third time this season and has accrued 60 or more receiving yards in five of his last six games played.

Larry Johnson saw his nine-game scoring streak fall to the wayside, but he reached the 100-yard mark for the eighth time this season and sixth time in seven games. If Johnson can match his season average of 109.3 rushing yards per game in the final four weeks, he'll finish the year with 1,749 rushing yards.

Backup tight end Steve Heiden was the recipient of two fourth-quarter touchdown passes off the arm of Cleveland backup Derek Anderson. Heiden caught five passes for 26 yards as a safety valve for Anderson. He'll be interesting to watch in the final weeks of the season.

Anderson performed brilliantly in relief of injured starter Charlie Frye to engineer the victory over Kansas City. He completed 12-of-21 attempts for 171 yards wit two touchdowns and one interception. Anderson also rushed twice for 44 yards. He'll assume the reins this week against Pittsburgh on Thursday night.

Frye had completed 11-of-13 passes for 122 yards and one touchdown before departing with a broken wrist. Frye hooked up with Braylon Edwards for a touchdown before departing (three receptions for 36 yards).

Reuben Droughns was the subject of much rumor, conjecture and speculation in Cleveland after carrying the ball twice in the blowout loss to Cincinnati in Week 12. Droughns returned to the field and assumed control of the backfield, carrying the ball 14 times for 70 yards and a score, his fourth of the season. It appears that he'll be back in the top spot going forward. For what it's worth, backup Jason Wright accrued 95 yards of total offense (25 rushing and 70 receiving).

Chad Pennington took advantage of a porous Green Bay pass defense to complete 25-of-35 attempts for 263 yards, two touchdowns and two interceptions in the blowout win. Pennington has thrown three touchdown passes in his last two games and finishes with three favorable matchups in his final four games.

Jerricho Cotchery narrowly missed his second consecutive 100-yard receiving game, hauling in nine receptions for 99 yards and a score against the Packers.

Tight end Chris Baker matched a season-high with four receptions and established a new season-high with 50 receiving yards. Baker also scored for the first time since Week 3.

Second-year Jets back Cedric Houson made his pitch to claim the starting role with 105 rushing yards on 22 attempts with two short touchdown plunges against Green Bay. Houston has scored three touchdowns in the past two weeks and will continue in the vulture role at a minimum, with Leon Washington working into the mix (seven carries for 40 yards and a touchdown).

Donald Driver caught only three passes in this game, but did a great job to hang onto a bullet from Brett Favre for a short touchdown. Driver finished with 41 receiving yards.

Ahman Green continued his strong comeback campaign with another big day on the ground. Green rushed for 102 yards and added four receptions for 38 yards against the Jets. He's topped 100 rushing yards on five occasions and has contributed at least 80 total yards in eight of 10 games in which he's played.

LaDainian Tomlinson made another step toward history with two rushing touchdowns and 178 rushing yards against the Bills. Tomlinson has rushed for 100 yards in six consecutive games and has accounted for multiple scores in eight consecutive games.

Antonio Gates scored for the second consecutive week, this time by the conventional quarterback to tight end toss. Gates caught seven passes for 90 yards in this game, his highest yardage total of the season. Fantasy owners are thankful to see Gates back in the mix as the fantasy playoffs begin.

J.P. Losman couldn't connect with Lee Evans, but he did throw for 184 yards and a touchdown in Sunday's loss to San Diego. Peerless Price and Robert Royal were the recipients of his touchdown strikes.

Willis McGahee was limited to 26 yards on the ground and was no doubt giving his fantasy owners fits, but his two-yard plunge into the end zone made everything right. McGahee has now scored three touchdowns in the last two weeks.

San Francisco receiver Antonio Bryant was the lone bright spot for the offense on Sunday. He caught four passes for 79 yards and scored his third touchdown of the season. Bryant had recorded two receptions in four consecutive games with fewer than 60 receiving yards in each prior to Sunday's strong effort.

Maurice Jones-Drew continued his bid toward claiming Offensive Rookie of the Year honors with another big effort against the Jaguars. Jones-Drew carried the ball five times for 46 yards, including a 32-yard touchdown run. Jones-Drew has now scored in four consecutive games and has accrued 817 total yards and nine touchdowns this season (eight different games).

Jaguars quarterback David Garrard posted his third strong start in his last five by picking apart a surging Miami defense. Garrard completed 16-of-22 passes for 229 yards and two scores. He has thrown multiple touchdown passes in three of his last five starts.

Matt Jones has now scored in back-to-back games for Jacksonville, and assumed the receiving lead with six receptions for 128 yards against Miami. Jones leads the Jaguars with 451 receiving yards in spite of missing three games entirely and much of two others with a variety of injuries. Jones makes for a strong play in Week 14 against smaller Indianapolis cornerbacks.

Dolphins receiver Marty Booker continued to be Joey Harrington's top receiver in the red zone, catching five balls for 61 yards and a touchdown. Booker has scored in four of his last six games and has averaged six receptions in his last three outings.

Booker found the end zone, but Chris Chambers finally gave loyal fantasy owners something to cheer about. Chambers hadn't topped 70 receiving yards in any of his first 11 games this season, but he tallied eight catches for 121 yards on Sunday.

The Oakland defense appeared as one of the sleeper picks for this week against Houston, and delivered in a 23-14 loss. Oakland's defense contributed a touchdown, five sacks and generated two turnovers.

Wali Lundy rushed for 33 yards and a touchdown, but the story of the day for the Texans offense was the re-emergence of Ron Dayne. Dayne carried the ball 18 times for 95 yards (5.3 yards per carry average) to jump into the backfield by committee situation in Houston.

Justin Fargas scored the lone Oakland offensive touchdown (49 yards rushing), but ReShard Lee was the more productive back. Lee carried the ball six times for 42 yards and added five receptions for 57 yards.

Giants quarterback Eli Manning bounced back in a big way against the Cowboys on Sunday after a week of tremendous criticism. Manning completed 67 percent of his pass attempts for 270 yards and two touchdowns without a turnover. Manning's last two multi-touchdown efforts came against Dallas.

Marion Barber III made another strong case to Bill Parcells that he should assume the role of primary ball carrier in the Dallas backfield, and no one should argue at this point. Barber plunged into the end zone twice and contributed 76 rushing yards on 12 carries. He is averaging a robust 5.2 yards per carry this season and has piled up 13 total touchdowns.

Dallas receiver Terrell Owens had several drops once again, but still hauled in eight balls for 84 yards as his connection with Tony Romo continues to grow.

Jeremy Shockey caught six balls for 65 yards and a touchdown in Week 13. Shockey ended his three-game scoring drought with his early touchdown reception. He's alternated great and mediocre games for the past six weeks.

Plaxico Burress rallied from a week of criticism to catch four passes for 43 yards and the late tying touchdown on a bullet from Eli Manning. He was also flagged for a 15-yard penalty for a late block as the whistle blowed, showing the team that he heard the messages of the past week loud and clear. Burress has scored in five of the last six games in which he's appeared.

And how about the big pick-up of this week? Martin Gramatica paid huge dividends in his first game as the Cowboys kicker, connecting on 3-of-4 field goals with two PATs and the game-winner. Jason Witten shortened Gramatica's usual celebration by hugging him with the hope of preventing an injury. Gramatica is a top waiver wire player this week.

Ben Roethlisberger took advantage of a matchup against the struggling Tampa Bay secondary. He completed only 12-of-25 attempts, but completed touchdown passes to tight ends Jerame Tuman and Heath Miller. Roethlisberger threw only one interception on the day. Nate Washington led all Pittsburgh receivers with three receptions for 78 yards.

Tatum Bell of the Broncos returned to the lineup to reclaim the starting tailback role from a struggling Mike Bell. He reported no pain in his toes and carried the ball 23 times for 133 yards in his first game back after missing two straight games and three of the previous four Broncos contests. For what it's worth, only 21 of his 133 yards came in the second half.

Seattle kicker Josh Brown missed his first two field goal attempts in the Sunday night matchup against Denver, but he righted the ship and made them when they counted. Brown kicked a 50-yard field goal with five seconds left for his fourth game-winning field goal of the year. He converted three second-half field goals against the Broncos.

Shaun Alexander was bottled up early, but better offensive line play and a couple of big runs in the second half allowed him to finish with 90 yards and a score.

Darrell Jackson caught two big passes on the drive that ended with Alexander's touchdown. He finished with six catches for 91 yards to lead all receivers on Sunday night.

The struggles of Rex Grossman continue with another three-interception game. Grossman completed just 6-of-19 attempts for a meager 34 yards. The matchup looked enticing against a struggling Minnesota pass defense, but Grossman was unable to find any rhythm all day. As such, Bernard Berrian (21 yards) and Muhsin Muhammad (five yards) offered no help to fantasy owners. The schedule looks bright for Grossman and the Bears to close the season, but fantasy owners certainly can't trust his right arm with the playoffs on tap. Grossman has turned the ball over 18 times since Week 6.

Minnesota quarterback Brad Johnson found himself on the bench after tossing four interceptions and completing just 11-of-26 pass attempts for 73 yards. Tarvaris Jackson or Brooks Bollinger may assume the reins in Minnesota after relieving Johnson this week.

Starting tailback Thomas Jones of the Bears struggled to 32 yards on 12 carries against the stout Minnesota run defense. This lackluster performance ended a streak of three games for Jones with at least 99 rushing yards.

The Bengals defense did a tremendous job in shutting down a Ravens offense that had scored 24 or more points in the games since Brian Billick took over play-calling. Jamal Lewis posted a solid yardage total (61 rushing and 26 receiving), but his scoring streak ended at two games. Todd Heap caught four passes for 27 yards. It marked the fourth time in five games that the big tight end was held without a score after his torrid start to the season.

Chris Henry of the Bengals had been plugged in to many lineups as a third receiver. He failed to record a reception this week.

The Cardinals piled up points this week, but the Rams did a great job in shutting down Anquan Boldin. The star receiver was limited to two receptions for 32 yards in the win.

Washington receiving star Chris Cooley, who had scored in five of his previous six games, was shut down by the Falcons on Sunday. Cooley caught two passes for 12 yards, his lowest receiving total since Week 1.

Detroit quarterback Jon Kitna threw for 314 yards and a touchdown on 22-of-38 passing, but also took five sacks and turned the ball over four times against the Patriots. It marked his 10th consecutive game with at least one interception this season. Does Josh McCown's appearance as a receiver (two receptions for 15 yards) mean that the end is near for Kitna in Detroit?

Furrey was the star on Sunday, as New England worked to shut down Roy Williams. Williams contributed three receptions for 50 yards in a quiet performance.

Tom Brady threw for 305 yards, but failed to find the end zone against Detroit. After a strong start to the season, Brady has thrown one or zero touchdowns in four of his last five games.

Leading receiver Ben Watson of the Patriots was limited to three receptions for 41 yards, but lost a fumble. Watson has accrued 40 or more receiving yards in six of his last seven games.

Reggie Wayne caught three passes against Tennessee to reach the 1,000-yard mark for the third consecutive season. However, Wayne was scoreless for only the second time in his last eight games and accrued only 57 receiving yards.

Fantasy owners counted on a huge follow-up effort from Joseph Addai after his four-touchdown performance in Week 12. They were left wanting on Sunday, as Addai tallied only 56 rushing yards on 16 attempts and watched Dominic Rhodes score the lone rushing touchdown of the year (12 carries for 39 yards).

Ben Utecht was one of the top sleeper plays at tight end this week after the injury to Dallas Clark in Week 12. Utecht contributed one reception for 18 yards in the defeat.

Kellen Winslow, Jr. contributed his lone catch of the day in overtime to help the Browns defeat Kansas City, but that's small consolation for fantasy owners expecting a big effort in the showdown against Tony Gonzalez. Winslow, Jr. was targeted just three times on the day and finished with one reception.

Laveranues Coles commanded extra attention from the Green Bay secondary and was limited to three receptions for 28 yards in the blowout win. This game marked his lowest reception and yardage totals since Week 5. Coles has now finished five games with 40 or fewer receiving yards this season (four 100-yard games).

Rookie receiver Greg Jennings started the season strong, but has struggled of late. He has not scored since Week 5 and was limited to two receptions for 14 yards against the Jets. Jennings has accrued 50 or fewer receiving yards in five of six games in which he's played since the Packers' Week 5 bye.

After a monster performance in Week 11, Lee Evans has been quieted in two consecutive games. Evans caught five passes for 45 yards in the loss after catching five passes for 58 yards in Week 12. He has tallied fewer than 60 receiving yards in six games this season.

Drew Brees had carried fantasy owners for weeks, so it's hard to put him in the Flops column following Sunday's win. However, Brees contributed only 186 passing yards and one touchdown (on a shovel pass to Bush) in this all-important Week 13 matchup.

To that end, Devery Henderson jumped in the rankings boards ahead of this contest with word that Marques Colston would sit this one out. Henderson responded with two catches for 14 yards. He's hit big in two weeks and swung and missed twice.

Fellow New Orleans receiver Terrance Copper was shut out altogether after scoring in three consecutive games.

This weekend's performance takes nothing away from the tremendous season offered by Frank Gore, but he was silenced by the New Orleans defense in this huge spot. Gore carried the ball 13 times for 40 yards and added five receptions for 28 yards. It was a decent effort for those in point-per-reception leagues, but a minimal effort elsewhere.

San Francisco quarterback Alex Smith completed 50 percent of his pass attempts for 171 yards, one touchdown and three interceptions in the loss. He has thrown five interceptions against two touchdowns in his last two games. Smith last topped 200 passing yards in Week 6.

Sammy Morris of the Dolphins couldn't build on his strong Thanksgiving Day performance in place of injured starter Ronnie Brown. Morris carried the ball 12 times for 47 yards in the loss to Jacksonville.

Texans quarterback David Carr rolled up 300 yards last week in a loss to the Jets, but he posted only 32 passing yards against the Raiders on Sunday. Andre Johnson caught one pass for nine yards. After subtracting the yardage from five sacks recorded by Oakland, the Texans generated minus-5 yards in passing offense and won.

Take nothing away from the ability of Tony Romo and the beauty of his 42-yard strike to Jason Witten to set up the game-winning field goal. But, Romo was unable to continue his fantasy magic on Sunday. He completed 20-of-34 pass attempts for 257 yards and two early interceptions.

Dallas receiver Terry Glenn was also quiet in the hard-fought game, contributing four receptions for 52 yards in the win.

Julius Jones played a minimal role in Sunday's win over the Giants. He rushed 11 times for 24 yards and caught one pass for 11 yards. It appears the Marion Barber III is supplanting Jones as the top option in the Dallas backfield down the stretch, as he's forced an equitable split of the workload in recent weeks.

The Steelers entered the game banged-up in the secondary, but Bruce Gradkowski was unable to find success downfield. He completed 20-of-34 attempts for 175 yards, took five sacks and threw three interceptions. Joey Galloway caught only three passes for 37 yards.

Gradkowski's struggles tie directly back to the team's inability to consistently run the ball. Carnell Williams rushed 11 times for 27 yards and added four receptions for 30 yards. He also lost a fumble on the day and has now rushed for fewer than 50 yards in seven games this season. Williams has scored only once all year.

Steelers running back Willie Parker continues to struggle as fantasy owners approach the playoffs. He carried the ball 22 times for a meager 61 yards (2.8 yards per carry) and added one reception for 25 yards. Parker next faces the Browns on Thursday night.

Seattle quarterback Matt Hasselbeck completed 16-of-28 attempts for a pedestrian 168 yards with one interception in the 23-20 win over Denver. Hasselbeck looked shaky at times, and later in the game, Mike Holmgren went away from the pass in several manageable third-down situations. He did narrowly miss a touchdown when Darrell Jackson was downed at the one on a fourth-quarter pass. Keep an eye on Hasselbeck in practice as the week unfolds.

Deion Branch tallied just three receptions for 23 yards in the win.

Cutler delivered in his first start, but Javon Walker was a non-factor on Sunday night. Walker caught two balls for 17 yards as Denver re-established the running game.

96347.summary: Genetically modified organisms, or GMOs, remain divisive in countries where they're established and those that have yet to approve any GMO crops. Here are five things to know about the technology:

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: Genetically modified organisms, or GMOs, remain divisive in countries where they're established and those that have yet to approve any GMO crops. Here are five things to know about the technology:
metadata.source: Corn, soybeans and cotton are the most widely-grown genetically engineered crops on U.S. farms. The U.S. Department of Agriculture, which regulates GMO crops, approved genetically modified varieties of alfalfa, canola, sugar beets, squash and papayas. Regulators last year blessed genetically engineered potatoes, apples, and a salmon that grows faster than conventional versions and represented the first biotech animal cleared for human consumption.

5105.summary: Heading into this year’s Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity in the south of France, its now-public parent company Ascential PLC has offered a glimpse into the ad festival’s financials for the first time.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: Heading into this year’s Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity in the south of France, its now-public parent company Ascential PLC has offered a glimpse into the ad festival’s financials for the first time.
supported-summary-entities: Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity
metadata.source:
The Cannes Lions International Festival of Creativity is the largest and most prestigious event in the advertising and marketing industries, drawing in thousands of attendees to drink rosé on the banks of the French Riviera and celebrate the year’s best work.

For attendees, the week in the south of France doesn’t come cheap—which is good news for the conference business.

Ascential ASCL -0.60 % PLC, the parent company of the Cannes Lions festival, went public on the London Stock Exchange LSE 0.00 % in February, offering a glimpse into the famed advertising event’s financials for the first time.

The Cannes Lions festival generated £42.5 million ($61.5 million) in revenue for 2015, up 3.7% from the prior year’s event, according to the annual report for Ascential published in April. Excluding foreign exchange fluctuations, Cannes Lions’ revenue would have risen 18% from 2014.

The annual report didn’t disclose profits for Cannes Lions. Ascential’s exhibitions and festivals segment, which includes Cannes Lions, had an adjusted operating profit of £54.7 million ($79.1 million) for 2015.

The annual event primarily makes money from award entry fees and tickets, which together represented 83% of the event’s revenues in 2015, according to an Ascential analyst presentation in April. Entry fees, excluding late fees, for this year’s awards ranged from €499 to €1,399 each ($565 to $1583).

“The growth of the festival really I think is an indication of just how complex marketing is at the moment,” said Lions Festivals Chief Executive Philip Thomas. “Cannes is a place that people come to try and understand that [complexity] and see the greatest work in the world that’s being created in different mediums.”

The upcoming Cannes Lions festival, to be held from June 18 to June 25, includes a high-profile line up of agency CEOs, chief marketing officers, tech executives and popular celebrities for workshops, presentations, networking sessions and award presentations. Last year’s event had 9,531 paying delegates and more than 40,000 entries from 90 countries, “cementing its position as the ‘must attend’ and ‘must enter’ festival for the branded communications industry,” according to Ascential’s annual report.

There are various ticket packages for attendees depending on access level and duration. For example, a “classic” pass—which includes eight days of full access to talks, awards and networking at Cannes Lions and access to the specialist events, Cannes Innovation and Cannes Entertainment, costs €3,050 ($3,452). An eight-day “complete gold” ticket, which comes with line-skip privileges at mainstage talks and awards ceremonies and VIP access to the opening and closing galas, costs €5,050 ($5,716). There are lower priced ticket options for attendees who only want to attend the social and networking events and for professionals under the age of 30.

“For the volume and the value that you get, I question whether that’s a high price at all,” Mr. Thomas said of the festival’s ticket prices. “When people attend or when they partner with us they tend to see the value very quickly. That value is clearly something that they want to repeat year on year on year.”

Agencies can spend several hundreds of thousands of dollars more on other Cannes-related expenses, such as travel and accommodation for attendees, parties and speaker fees, people familiar with the matter said. On top of that, many agencies have dedicated staff to strategize and prepare Cannes entries and promote campaigns ahead of the festival.

About 9% of Cannes Lions’ revenue last year came from sponsorships, or fees paid by companies to promote their businesses during the events, according to the April analyst presentation. Sponsorships can range from $10,000 to a couple hundred thousand dollars, Mr. Thomas said. The remaining 8% of Cannes Lions revenue last year came from services, which include trophy sales and an online archive of historic entries, the presentation said.

According to Ascential’s annual report, new delegate propositions and new forms of sponsorship at Cannes Lions have contributed to the business media and events company’s organic growth for the year. To help reach new customers and deepen its product coverage, Cannes Lions has added show extensions such as Lions Health, an event launched in 2014 that is focused on health-care communications, and Lions Innovation, an event launched last year focused on data and technology specialists in the creative space. This year, Cannes Lions is presenting a new event, Lions Entertainment, which is focused on branded entertainment.

The festival is the largest event owned by Ascential, whose portfolio includes fashion information provider WGSN and trade shows such as Money 20/20 and the Spring and Autumn Fairs. Cannes Lions represented 13% of Ascential’s total revenue last year.

Ascential’s shares in London have increased 27% since its February IPO. It has a market capitalization of roughly £1.02 billion ($1.47 billion).

Write to Nathalie Tadena at nathalie.tadena@wsj.com

17377.summary: Gabriela Alban was found dead at the Camps Bay Retreat Boutique Hotel in Cape Town

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: Gabriela Alban was found dead at the Camps Bay Retreat Boutique Hotel in Cape Town
supported-summary-entities: the Camps Bay Retreat Boutique Hotel
metadata.source:
08/05/2015 AT 06:30 PM EDT

A Los Angeles woman who once ran a successful PR company catering to clients like Ford and Payless ShoeSource was

at a posh resort in South Africa – and her Guatemalan boyfriend has been arrested and charged with premeditated murder in connection with her death.

The July 29 killing of Gabriela Alban, 39, at the Camps Bay Retreat Boutique Hotel in Cape Town, where rooms cost up to $10,000 a night, has left her friends shocked.

"It is devastating," friend Aida Phillips tells PEOPLE. "I just found out she was dating this guy a few months ago. She was super happy."

"She was the sweetest, most caring woman," says another friend, Monica Prieto. "One of those women that like to nurture others, which led her to some toxic relationships with troubled men."

"It was a really big shock," says another friend, Ivette Serrano. "Nobody really knows what happened."

An official cause of death has not yet been released. Her 41-year-old boyfriend, Diego Dougherty Novella, who was reportedly a member of a powerful Central American family, was arrested after her body was found.

Alban was "very focused on her company and career, her dogs and family," Prieto says. "Smart women sometimes fall for the wrong men."

Prieto adds that Alban was "absolutely loved" in the PR industry. "The media world is brutal, lots of envy, backstabbing, however I never met one person, not one, that did not love her. Not one."

Alban, who grew up in Los Angeles, attended Pepperdine University in Malibu. She started Conexión, a PR company focused on the Hispanic media market with Martín Llorens, a well-known author and a renowned fashion and lifestyle expert, in 2002.

Llorens posted a tribute to his friend and business partner on Facebook:

"She was fun and very stylish," remembers Serrano.

Serrano says Alban was passionate about her work and making her business a success.

"She was very invested in her business," says Serrano. "She was well known in Los Angeles. She was very media savvy."

As Novella sits in a jail cell awaiting his next court appearance, friends of Alban still struggle to understand their loss.

"I can't even begin to tell you how upset her friends are," says Phillips.

16594.summary: You can't make up for lost time, but that doesn't mean you don't have options.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: You can't make up for lost time, but that doesn't mean you don't have options.
metadata.source:
You’re rounding the corner toward retirement age with not nearly enough set aside.

We tell young people to start saving for retirement from their first job and not to quit, because even small sums can grow staggeringly large with enough decades of compound returns. But maybe you bumped along from paycheck to paycheck, never saving much. Or maybe you tried to save but got slammed with unexpected setbacks like a late-in-life job loss.

Let’s be clear: You can’t make up for lost time.

But don’t give up — you do have options. Any money you can set aside can help you make retirement more comfortable. Here’s what you need to do:

This means working longer, working part time in retirement or both. You’ll have more time to save, your savings will have more time to grow, and you’ll shorten the full-retirement period you’ll need to cover. That’s a nice way to say you’ll have fewer work-free years before you die.

If working longer in your current job feels like a death sentence, start looking around for paying gigs you might enjoy in retirement. Working longer may have an upside: People who voluntarily work in retirement often say their jobs keep them active and engaged.

If you start taking Social Security benefits before your full retirement age — which is currently 66 and rising to 67 for people born in 1960 and later — the “earnings test” will reduce your benefit by $1 for every $2 you earn over a certain limit ($15,720 in 2016). That reduction will end when you hit full retirement age.

Read More: 1 in 3 Americans Has Saved $0 for Retirement

The benefits of waiting are so great that it may be worth tapping whatever retirement funds you have so you can hold out until your full retirement age. If you sign up at age 62, you’ll lock in a permanently reduced check.

Most people are better off delaying their application at least until their full retirement age, currently 66 but rising to 67 for people born in 1960 or later. That would inflate a $1,500 monthly benefit to at least $2,000. If you waited until age 70, when benefits max out, the same check would grow to about $2,640 each month.

If you’re married, it’s particularly important for the higher earner to put off applying for as long as possible. When one of you dies, the survivor will get the larger of the two benefits you received as a couple. Maximizing that benefit can help keep the survivor’s final years from being a financial nightmare.

Rule of thumb: Every year you wait past age 62 adds about 7% to 8% to your eventual benefit.

Read More: The True Cost of a Bounced Check

If you have substantial home equity, you have a powerful asset to deploy for your retirement. You can:

New Jersey resident Walt Lukasik, 60, is investigating this option to salvage retirement plans that were upended by his wife’s cancer diagnosis 15 years ago. She hasn’t been able to work for the past eight years, and medical bills have sucked away any money they’d hoped to save, Lukasik says.

The combination of caregiving and worrying about retirement is taking its toll. “It’s killing me,” he says.

If he applies for a reverse mortgage in two years, it could pay off the $75,000 balance on their current mortgage and give them a monthly payment of about $390, according to the National Reverse Lenders Mortgage Association. If he waits until the mortgage is paid off in five years, the monthly payment would be closer to $800. Other payout options include a lump sum of $93,000 or a line of credit of more than $160,000.

Reverse mortgages are complex and can be costly, so they’re not a good fit for every situation. Counseling is mandatory and typically provided by nonprofit credit counseling agencies.

Read More: Everyday Investors Should Avoid Alternative Investments

Most U.S. parents are horrified by the notion of asking their children for money. Their kids often don’t feel the same way. A recent survey by Fidelity Investments found nine out of 10 parents think it would be unacceptable to become financially dependent on their offspring, but only three out of 10 adult children agreed with them.

If there’s any chance you may need your children to help you make ends meet, consider having the conversation sooner rather than later. Bringing up the issue may be painful and embarrassing. But at least you’ll know whether you can rely on their help, and they will have time to rearrange their finances to better offer it — while, of course, saving for their own retirement.

If worse comes to worst, Social Security alone can keep you above the poverty line — that’s why it was invented. You also may qualify for public benefits, such as subsidized housing, food benefits and lower-cost utilities. Start your search at Benefits.gov.

If consumer debt such as credit cards, medical bills and unsecured personal loans totals half or more of your gross income, explore your debt-relief options, including talking with an experienced bankruptcy attorney. You may be better off saving that money than using it to chip away at debt you can’t ultimately repay.

Read More: Key Financial Considerations for Your Encore Career

You don’t need a fortune. You do need a way to deal with an emergency or the flexibility to time your benefits better. Anything you can save will give you more choices in retirement. Having $10,000 in a savings account could pay for a new furnace or an unexpected medical bill. Boosting your savings more could allow you to delay Social Security or the start of a pension to get bigger checks.

This option is a long shot, but it may work for those with sufficient income to make a last, aggressive push to save for retirement.

You may be able to save a big chunk of your income if you’re entering the empty nest years and can funnel into retirement accounts money that you used to spend on raising and educating kids. Or maybe you’re just determined to slash expenses and buckle down to serious saving.

Let’s say you earn around $45,000. According to Social Security, your benefit at full retirement age will replace roughly 40% of what you make, or about $18,000 a year. Saving 20% to 30% of your income during your last 15 years of work could give you a nest egg big enough to prevent your lifestyle from falling off a cliff in retirement. (This assumes that you can manage a 6% average annual return, inflation averages 3% and that you’ll live on about 60% to 70% of your pre-retirement income for 20 years.)

If you’re able to pull this off — and that’s a big if — you can go a long way toward closing the retirement gap.

31768.summary: For most of us, a train journey means a sleepy-eyed commute to work. For trainiacs, they're another entry in the little black book.But for a lucky few, a rail journey is an expedition through

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: For most of us, a train journey means a sleepy-eyed commute to work. For trainiacs, they're another entry in the little black book. But for a lucky few, a rail journey is an expedition through
metadata.source:
Sister train to Europe's Venice Simplon Orient-Express, an open-air observation car allows heady aromas of the Orient to waft onboard. Accompanied by the tinkle of ivory, the Piano Bar is the social hub where tall Singapore Slings garnished with fresh fruit are de rigeur.

Upper and lower berths and en suite bathrooms complete the picture in three cabin configurations: Pullman, State and Presidential.

Cost: Pullman Cabin US$3,070; Presidential Suite US$6,130.http://www.orient-express.com/

Hiram Bingham was an American historian credited with bringing the ancient Inca site of Machu Picchu to world attention.

Ascending almost 2,500 meters above sea level to the ancient Peruvian ruins, the Orient-Express train that bears his name is one of the shortest luxury trains in the world. Heavily geared towards gastronomy during the four hours it takes to climb heavenwards through the spectacular Andes mountains, this is the easy way to tackle the Inca Trail.

Don't forget to take your party frock for the cocktail party on the return evening journey.

Boarding: Poroy or Machu Pichu.

With just a handful of journeys scheduled each summer, The Southern Spirit traverses four states through southeastern Australia's Outback.

More a rail cruise than a point-to-point journey, daily whistle-stop tours set the schedule, allowing passengers to explore regional Australia. Highlights include Byron Bay, the Hunter Valley vineyards along with free-range Taronga Western Plains Zoo at Dubbo.

Luxuriously styled, guests need only decide the level of elegance required, in either Gold or Platinum Class cabins. Private carriages also available for charter.

78700.summary: MARCO Pierre White Jr’s mother has revealed her agony at watching her son’s shocking behaviour on Big Brother. Mati Conejero – who is in the middle of a bitter divorce from chef Marco – says she br…

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: MARCO Pierre White Jr’s mother has revealed her agony at watching her son’s shocking behaviour on Big Brother. Mati Conejero – who is in the middle of a bitter divorce from chef Marco – says she br…
metadata.source:
The estranged wife of Marco Sr said she broke down in tears watching him

MARCO Pierre White Jr’s mother has revealed her agony at watching her son’s shocking behaviour on Big Brother.

Mati Conejero – who is in the middle of a bitter divorce from chef Marco – says she broke down in tears watching her ‘lost’ boy on TV.

She told the Mail On Sunday: “I broke down when I saw that for how lost he is. I feel so helpless that I can’t do anything, but how would you feel when your beautiful baby boy ends up a man covered in tattoos, with the word ‘Broken’ across his face.”

The 51-year-old is estranged from both Marco and his brother Luciano and is awaiting trial on charges of assaulting them both – something which she vehemently denies.

The mother-of-three watched in horror as Marco took part in some shocking sex scenes on the channel 5 show – which included him sucking a woman’s nipple, despite being engaged before he got the boot on Friday evening.

She added: “In another scene on Big Brother I saw him crying. Even at the time, I thought he was not distressed about Big Brother – but about his life outside.

“I had hoped he might learn some lessons in there about what is and isn’t socially acceptable. But Mini doesn’t know any boundaries and now he’s in a place where he can’t control the situation. One of the girls on the show said he was like a six-year-old boy.”

The final straw for Mati – who says she fears for her son’s future – came when she watched him begged Laura to ‘strangle’ him with a belt for sexual pleasure.

“I don’t want to say bad things about my son, whom I love dearly. But I just don’t know what to do to help him. I worry it’s too late. The strangling thing was horrific to see, although I do think that Big Brother was irresponsible to have shown it,” she said.

“As his mother, I don't approve of Big Brother showing him as a sexual predator. It tears me apart to say it, but I feel there's no hope for him. Watching Big Brother is like watching my son die before my eyes.”

Yesterday Marco said he was happy to be out of the house and he wasted no time in hitting the town – but his fiancée was nowhere in sight after she failed to show up for his eviction.

Speaking to the Sun Online, he declared: "I was happy I’d done my time there, I made some great friends – But I was ready to leave, I just want to move on with my life."

13890.summary: A young man has been charged with trespass after being rescued from a Sydney rooftop.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: A young man has been charged with trespass after being rescued from a Sydney rooftop.
metadata.source:
An unresponsive young man has been found lying atop a 50cm-wide wall, seven metres above the ground, on a Sydney rooftop.

Bomb squad and rescue officers were deployed after neighbours suspected a prowler was lurking on the common brick wall separating a home from a hotel just before midnight on Friday.

The 21-year-old was safely retrieved and hospitalised as a precaution, before he was taken to Surry Hills police station and charged with trespass. He has been granted bail to appear in court on November 24.

34859.summary: Equity-indexed annuities can be confusing to understand, but for conservative investors, they can be valuable savings plans.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: Equity-indexed annuities can be confusing to understand, but for conservative investors, they can be valuable savings plans.
metadata.source:
An equity-indexed annuity (EIA) is an alternative savings plan for conservative investors. It can come as an immediate or deferred annuity, so the periodic payments promised in the contract are delayed. An investor may take on more risk compared to fixed or variable annuities. The returns are linked to the performance of a particular stock market index, often the S&P 500 or the Dow Jones Industrial Average (DJIA). The performance also depends on the terms of the contract. However, these instruments have the benefit of more potential return while providing the traditional benefits of being an annuity.

EIA History These annuities came onto the scene in the 1990s and have been sold at insurance companies. They follow the rise in stock market values and are considered an investment that could help seniors, who were able to ensure that their money was protected and growing, with their retirement income needs.

The investment tool's popularity soon took off at the turn of the millennium, with sales in the billions. The industry changed and the annuities became more complex. The tools had a variety of fees and charges, limitations on accumulation, calculations of index values, along with some other features.

Between 2003 and 2004 alone, sales doubled, going from $14 billion to nearly $22 billion, respectively. Sales were nearly $25 billion in 2007. In June 2008 more than $123 billion was invested in indexed annuities, Christopher Cox, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, stated at the time. Sales increased 45% in the first six months of 2009.

In 2008 the Securities Exchange Commission cracked down on the abusive sales practices used to promote the product to seniors. An inquiry at a national seniors summit revealed that EIAs were among the securities involved in senior investment fraud. The SEC worked on a new rule that would consider EIAs securities, and therefore would have protections afforded by the securities law.

EIAs Differ from the Other Types of Annuities An EIA's return is more interchangeable than a fixed annuity's, according to Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA), but this isn't the case when compared to a variable annuity; the return is not as much. The guaranteed interest rate is at a minimum; although, it's combined with an interest rate linked to a market index. It's the guaranteed interest rate that lessens their market risk; this differs from variable annuities. Also, when the stock market rises these investments are likely to have more gains than traditional fixed annuities.

The most common features that impact the return on equity-linked annuities are the participation rates, the spread, margin and asset fee, and the interest rate caps. Participation rates determine the amount of gain in the index that will be credited to the annuity. This would mean, for example, that if an insurance company sets the participation rate at 90%, the annuity would only be credited 90% of the gain.

A spread, margin or asset fee in addition to, or instead of, a participation rate are sometimes used with these types of annuities, and the percentage will be taken away from any gain in the index linked to the annuity, according to FINRA. Some EIAs will restrict the upper limit on your return, according to FINRA.

The typical methods in which the equity insurance annuities are calculated include the annual reset method, the point-to-point method and the high-water-mark method. The annual rest method looks at the changes in the index from the beginning to the end of the year, while neglecting declines; the point-to-point method looks at the change in the index at two points in time; the high-water mark approach narrows in on the index value at typically the annual anniversaries and takes the highest of these values and compares it to the index level at the start of the term.

46755.summary: How do robots resolve problems? These four animated machines do so with dubstep in this beautifully constructed eye candy.

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: How do robots resolve problems? These four animated machines do so with dubstep in this beautifully constructed eye candy.
metadata.source:
How do robots resolve problems? These four animated machines do so with dubstep.

Produced by Fluxel Media with beats from musician Andrew “Nostalgia” Hill, the “Dubstep Dispute” video is beautifully constructed eye candy. Complementing the visuals is a remix of Muse’s “Knights of Cydonia.”

Fluxel used 3D technology from Luxology, After Effects, Optical Flares and Adobe Audition to match the sights with the sounds.

“Rigging the characters and environment was not overly complex but there was a fair amount of channel linking to keep all of the lights, material luminence and robot animations in sync with the music track,” Fluxel says.

20457.summary: GENEVA — FIFA acknowledged Wednesday that past World Cups were awarded based on bribes, and the organization wants US prosecutors to give it “tens of millions of dollars” seized from th…

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: GENEVA — FIFA acknowledged Wednesday that past World Cups were awarded based on bribes, and the organization wants US prosecutors to give it “tens of millions of dollars” seized from th…
metadata.source:
GENEVA — FIFA acknowledged Wednesday that past World Cups were awarded based on bribes, and the organization wants US prosecutors to give it “tens of millions of dollars” seized from the former FIFA officials who took the cash.

FIFA submitted a 22-page claim to the US Attorney’s Office in New York on Tuesday that seeks a big share in restitution from more than $190 million already forfeited by soccer and marketing officials who pleaded guilty in the sprawling corruption case.

Tens of millions of dollars more is likely to be collected by US authorities when sentences are handed down, and from dozens of officials currently indicted but who have denied bribery charges or are fighting extradition.

FIFA claims it is the victim of corrupt individuals, despite widespread criticism that bribe-taking was embedded in its culture in the presidencies of Joao Havelange and Sepp Blatter, who was forced from office after 17 years by the current scandal.

“The convicted defendants abused the positions of trust they held at FIFA and other international football organizations and caused serious and lasting damage to FIFA,” FIFA President Gianni Infantino said Wednesday in a statement. “The monies they pocketed belonged to global football and were meant for the development and promotion of the game. FIFA as the world governing body of football wants that money back and we are determined to get it no matter how long it takes.”

In documents seen by the Associated Press, FIFA asks for:

• $28.2 million for years of payments, including bonuses, flights and daily expenses, to officials it now says are corrupt

• $10 million for the “theft” of money that FIFA officials transferred as bribes to then-executive committee members to vote for South Africa as 2010 World Cup host

• “substantial” cost of legal bills since separate US and Swiss federal probes of corruption in international soccer were revealed last May

• damages for harm to its reputation, plus other bribes and kickbacks for media rights to non-FIFA competitions but “which were made possible because of the value of the FIFA brand”

“FIFA has become notable for the defendants’ bribery and corruption, not its many good works,” lawyers for soccer’s world body state in the claim. “FIFA is entitled to restitution for this harm to its business relationships, reputation and intangible property.”

FIFA’s grab for a share of the money sets up a battle with two of its regional confederations — CONMEBOL, the South American confederation, and CONCACAF, the body running soccer in North America. It was officials and competitions from those regions that were most involved in the corruption crisis.

It also signals a change in strategy for FIFA, after months of senior officials distancing Zurich from the scandal, instead blaming confederations which are beyond its control.

Most of the already seized money — $151.7 million — will come from Brazilian marketing executive Jose Hawilla, whose group of agencies were heavily involved with matches CONCACAF and CONMEBOL controlled but not FIFA directly.

In an initial claim for $28.2 million, FIFA specifies an amount for each of 20 men from the Americas over many years that it says it should be repaid from money held by US authorities.

FIFA wants more than $5.3 million it spent on Chuck Blazer, the disgraced American official who has pleaded guilty, allocates $4.4 million of its claim for former FIFA vice president Jack Warner, and $3.5 million for Ricardo Teixeira, Havelange’s former son-in-law from Brazil.

Warner, a long-time powerbroker from Trinidad and Tobago until resigning in a 2011 election bribery scandal, is identified by FIFA in its 22-page claim for receiving a $1 million bribe from 1998 World Cup bid candidate Morocco, and ensuring the $10 million bribe from South Africa was paid via a FIFA account in 2008.

FIFA claims a further $2 million for payments to Jeffrey Webb, the Cayman Islands banker who was arrested at a luxury Zurich hotel last May, and now lives at his home near Atlanta, Georgia, awaiting sentencing in June.

“These dollars were meant to build football fields, not mansions and pools; to buy football kits, not jewelry and cars; and to fund youth player and coach development, not to underwrite lavish lifestyles for football and sports marketing executives,” Infantino said.

It is unclear how much influence Infantino, a former lawyer, had in the restitution claim since he was elected only three weeks ago, with strong support from voters in the Americas.

Infantino’s signature pitch to voters on election day was about finances, saying bluntly “It’s your money.” That resonated with members of CONMEBOL and CONCACAF, who have had a combined $20 million in central funding frozen by FIFA.

CONCACAF, based in Miami, has had its past three presidents implicated in the US case. But it has passed wide-ranging reforms to clean up its operations, and has targeted restitution money to rebuild.

“CONCACAF views itself as a victim of a number of the offenses described in the indictments and intends to seek restitution at the appropriate time,” the regional body said in a statement.

15138.summary: MySpace layouts is now the world's 9th most popular search term, according to the latest data coming out of Hitwise. ...

metadata.supported-summary-sentences: MySpace layouts is now the world's 9th most popular search term, according to the latest data coming out of Hitwise. ...
metadata.source:
MySpace layouts is now the world’s 9th most popular search term, according to the latest data coming out of Hitwise. We’ve already seen how huge the market is around feeding the MySpace beast (creating Flash widgets for social networking profiles), but MySpace layouts are also a massive driver of traffic. In fact, these sites are growing at about the same rate as MySpace itself - while the market share of visits to MySpace increased by 60% over the last 6 months, visits to the Hitwise “Web Development” category have increased by 57% over the same period. The top sites are no doubt making big bucks from their ad-supported business models.

Designers will also be overjoyed to learn that 9 of the top 10 web development sites in the world create MySpace layouts and flashing gifs. Additionally, it’s interesting to note that the top players are not simply those that have the highest Google ranking for “MySpace Layouts” (although there is some correlation).

So who are the big winners here? I thought I’d do a quick, easy-to-read, fun-for-all-the-family round up of the Top 10 companies in this booming sector. The following are ranked by market share.

The number one player, FreeWebLayouts, serves up fairly attractive off-the-shelf layouts. They’ve also made the process incredibly simple - click on any profile you like and you’ll instantly get some code to paste into your MySpace page. Popular backgrounds tend to include celebrities and movie imagery. It strikes me that this could be a huge opportunity for the movie studios: pay FreeWebLayouts to create and distribute a layout for your movie right before it comes out in theaters. It would be a cheap grassroots effort and could generate a large amount of buzz.

FreeWebLayouts also has a profile creator that lets users develop their own customized MySpace layouts - not to mention the hundreds of buttons, banners and add-ons that are available. Obviously all these elements will all link back to FreeWebLayouts when inserted into your MySpace profile - resulting in masses of traffic from MySpace.

The second biggest player in this market provides MySpace backgrounds and graphics with TV and music themes. What’s more, you can quickly grab the “MySpace codes” to drop into your site. HotFreeLayouts boasts that it has over 6,000 different layouts available, as well as customizable “MySpace banners”, animated gifs and polls. In fact, polls are another massively popular MySpace add-on - they’re provided by many of the top players. Additionally, you’ll notice that HotFreeLayouts has an extremely sparse (some might say ugly) design. This is a crucial point: when building tools for MySpace, your website design isn’t all that important.
